And any other Generals, did you see any of the other Generals at these gatherings?

Where we got together at the game farm, there was General Andries Terreblanche, that is Eugene Terreblanche's brother, he was there as well as other Generals.
	If I remember, that was the Saturday when we arrived there.  There was an Orde group which some people attended and some of the Generals were present there.  General Alec Cruywagen, he was also there at a certain stage.  Which day exactly it was, I cannot remember, but I know he was there.
An Orde group meeting, is that a closed meeting?
That is a closed meeting Chairperson.
Mr De Wet, can you speak a little bit slower.
During this operation, you received instructions from General Nico Prinsloo in order to make your vehicle available?
How did you see this instruction?

To me it was a question of a General giving me an instruction, we were together as a group.  He first asked me if I would make my vehicle available and I said yes, I would, and then I accepted his instruction and therefore I made it available.
An instruction from a private person?
No, it was an instruction from the General who was with us at the game farm.
Who acted on behalf of who?

Mr De Wet, please explain something to me.  I do not follow you very well.
	You are saying that at that stage you did what you did, because there was an instruction.  Didn't you want to do it yourself?
The struggle for freedom, it was also an ideal that I strived for, that was to obtain a Volkstaat.  Because I was told that there was a war, I voluntarily made myself available for the struggle.
So do I understand you correctly, the instruction only gave you the opportunity to do what you did?
The instruction was given to me and I reconciled myself with the instructions I received.

Just to link up with that question, this instruction that you have just testified about, this was in connection with your amnesty application, but you also testified that a long time before this operation, there were already talk of a revolution and war?
And you who worked very closely with Terreblanche, what was your opinion or your view with regards to the revolution and the war?

For me in the run up to the election, it was implicitly shown by the media and also by certain ANC members that no Volkstaat ideology would realise and together with what Mr Terreblanche said, the fact that we do not negotiate with the ANC and that if they do not give what we want, we will make war, and we will use bomb explosions or firearms, or whatever, and I reconciled myself with that, that we were going to take up the struggle against the ANC and the National Party.
Were you prepared to make war?
I was prepared to give my life for God, nation and father land.
Let's look at your vehicle again, you testified that you were told by General Prinsloo to remove the tow bar from your vehicle?
Cliffie Barnard whom you also testified about, do you know which rank he held?
Cliffie was a Colonel at the AWB.
How did you view him as a member of the AWB, what was his relationship with the Staff Generals, do you know?

As far as the Staff Generals is concerned, I do not know, but it appeared to me that him and Terreblanche had a very good relationship and that he did certain things for Mr Terreblanche when they were having meetings.
	When they were together in the office, nobody else was allowed.

Mr De Wet, in the evidence of the previous applicants, there was evidence which indicated at some stage it was said that the ranks were going to be abandoned, or were abandoned.  Can you remember such evidence?
Did you carry knowledge of that at that time?
I only went to Ventersdorp at a later stage, but Leon van der Merwe informed me that ranks would not exist because certain people were given instructions.
This was on the 21st or the 22nd, when I heard this from Van der Merwe?
That is before the election, before there were talk of bombs?
That is correct Chairperson.  He told me it was war.
The evidence which is aimed at trying to show that you reacted on the instructions of people who had rank, that is senseless because ranks no longer existed?
No, ranks didn't exist, but in my eyes, he was still a General.  General Prinsloo and Leon van der Merwe, a Brigadier, and the instructions I received from them, my instructions, I got from them.

But if you say there are no ranks any more, we are all equal, we are in battle, what is the worth of that evidence that you got instructions from a person with a certain rank?  I do not follow, please help me?
	If there weren't any ranks, what is the worth of that type of evidence?

It is when we addressed each other in public, I would not say General can I talk to you Captain, or whatever, but in the inner circles it still existed.
	We were together on the farm, and I spoke to someone, because I was brought up this way and also the fact that I did military service, I still used these ranks.

Let me just take you back to Exhibit F Chairperson, just to link up with the fact that statements were made pertaining to the fact that you just acted.  This was put to the other applicants, you acted not on behalf of the AWB.
	You testified that you were present at the meeting in Lichtenburg and you also saw the news report afterwards, is that correct?
It seems from the news report, the paper that the evening the hall was in darkness, do you know about that?

That is correct Chairperson, because of the bomb explosion which took place earlier that day somewhere next to the road, Mr Terreblanche told us, he told the public there, that he apologises for there being no power, because they brought the generators to generate power and he asked the people to apologise for the noise, because there is no power because of bomb explosions.
	Shortly after that he said that if the ANC and the National Party would not listen to our demand of a Volkstaat, there would be further bomb explosions, and these would be bigger than the ones already exploded.
Did you know who caused the bomb explosion at the power station?
Yes, I knew who were the two people involved in that.
De Wet Ras and Breytenbach, they also applied for amnesty.
You say De Wet Ras, there is a De Wet Strydom.
I apologise Chairperson, De Wet Strydom and Breytenbach were the two people.

The report goes further in the third paragraph, this is now Terreblanche speaking and the violence would not only take place within the Afrikaner area which they considered the Volkstaat, but also all over the country and then you would get nothing.
	That is what he said addressing the ANC.  Do you have any comment on this?

That was because of the utterances made by the ANC leaders.  The fact that they said one bullet, Kill a Boer, Kill a Farmer.  I think it was because of that, that if the ANC would not get anything out of this whole deal.

He goes further and he says at the meeting as well, that if they want the bombs to stop exploding, they must admit the nation's right which leads every nation to determine himself, with the right to self determination.
	Ferdi Hartzenberg was also at the meeting, is that correct?
That is correct.  And if I can remember correctly, Constand Viljoen was also there.
It seems quite evident that he was adamant on a white election or referendum so that the will of the nation which is quoted, so that it could be demonstrated?

Yes Chairperson, the Freedom Front, the AWB and the other right wing organisations, they often asked at these meetings that a white election could be held so that we can determine whether the whites wanted a general election or not.
What was your idea, and this idea did the AWB have the same objective?  What would have happened if the election took place with regards to the ideal of the AWB to establish a Volkstaat?
If the elections took place, no regard would have been given to a Volkstaat for the white Chairperson.
And he said that is why the AWB wanted to stop the election?
Mr De Wet, did you gain any personal benefit from these deeds?
What was your situation before this operation, you said you lost your job, but did you have ground on which you were farming?

After I worked for a while in the AWB, I started working for a private business.  I stayed on a farm on Ottosdal where I farmed.  When the Volkstaat became an ideal, we received the call up instructions, I lost all of that.  Today I've got nothing.
Did you commit any of these deeds out of malice?
No, I did not do it out of malice, I did it for the organisation, the AWB.
You did not testify about all of the meetings, but do you confirm the contents of your amnesty application?
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Mr De Wet, you gave evidence that you and Mr Potgieter who were your co-accused, was this a person that was accused with you or was he a State witness?
If I can remember correctly, he was at one stage charged, but he was only in prison for a while and then they used him as a State witness against us.

Mr De Wet,  in Exhibit F that was shown to you it is also said that earlier the week Mr Terreblanche said that if the Afrikaners before the 27th of April get a Volkstaat or be added into the constitution, there will be no force big enough to stop them, that hell will break loose and that neither me or Ferdi Hartzenberg will be able to stop that.  How did you interpret that, you said that you did read the article?
For me it was a very real instruction, that we will fight this war if we did not get what we wanted.
Did you understand out of this that these explosions would occur before the election?
Yes, before the election, with the election and I believe also after the elections, if the people were not arrested, there would be other bomb explosions and violence.
After the explosion at Bree Street, did you see it on TV at any stage during that day?
The Bree Street explosion we saw the Sunday evening on the television.
What impression did it leave with you, what you saw?

The person who read the news that evening said that it, I am going to use my own words, it made a very big impression on the world because there is someone who would like to disrupt the election.
	The media put it very clearly that someone wants to disrupt the election.
Did you believe that those explosions would prevent the elections from continuing?
Yes, it was very clear that with such explosions, there would be no election.

With the explosions that occurred the next day, that is now the Monday, the 25th of April in Germiston and the pipe bombings, as well as an explosion in Pretoria, what was your impression or global expression regarding those explosions?
That the chaos that would come from this, would disrupt the elections.
Would it have any purpose if you allowed to when the election started, to only begin with your bombings on that day?
No, it was a struggle that began in the early 1990's.

Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr De Wet, just referring to Exhibit F again, that is the newspaper article, the third paragraph on the left hand side.  The violence will not only take place in the area which the Afrikaners see as the Volkstaat, but across the whole country, and you will get bugger all or then you will get bugger all.  That is what he said of the ANC.
	What did he mean when he said that they would get bugger all?
That the country will never belong to the ANC at that stage.
Would there by anything left of the country for the ANC?
Yes, something would have been left.
What is "bugger-all" then?  What does that mean?
We would fight against the ANC, we would make war against them and that is the impression that I got from that.
Sir, I put it to you it is clear here, what you are saying is that there will be violence everywhere, and there will be nothing left for the ANC, isn't that so?
That is what it says yes, I saw it that there would be something left for a new beginning.
How do you make that conclusion?
Sir, I believe that you would have to plant a whole lot of bombs if you want to destroy the whole country in order for there to be nothing left.
I know that is the practical conclusion of that, the question is how did you understand that sentence?
For me it was that nothing would be given to the ANC, we will fight for what is ours.  That is how I interpreted it.
Sir, I want to put it to you that the other interpretation which is more clear, is that you will attempt to destroy everything, so that there will be nothing left?
I do not agree with that Mr Chairperson.
That is why you planted all these highly damaging bombs that destroyed buildings?
The bombs that were planted in Johannesburg, it was only a small part that was destroyed and it was not the whole of Johannesburg.
Mr De Wet, seeing the carnage caused by the Bree Street bomb on television on the Sunday night, did you think a few more of these big bombs would then bring an end to the election?
Yes, I believed that it was possible.
And that is all that you wanted to do, was to stop the election?
There was no need to throw pipe bombs, small pipe bombs at groups of people?
Sir, I was not the planner of the pipe bombs, so I cannot say what the purpose was of them.  If it was also possibly to create further chaos.
Did you participate in the throwing of the pipe bombs?
Mr Chairman, I was not part of it but I was present when it was demonstrated and I transported it from Koesterfontein to the game farm.
Mr De Wet, you gave evidence or testified as far as I remember that you reconciled yourself with the pipe bombs and that which was done with it?
In the light of that, can you maybe answer again to the question that Mr Landman asked you about why pipe bombs were used?
Mr Chairperson, all that I can add there is that that is to create further chaos in order to stop the election.  That is my personal opinion and that is how I saw it.
It is not a question that you cannot answer the question because you did not do the planning?
I did not do any planning regarding the pipe bombs because I did reconcile myself with the group with whom I was at that stage.
Mr De Wet, when you drew up your application for amnesty, did you try to put in all the facts that you knew, that might be relevant to your application?

Mr Chairperson, when my Advocates for Barnard, Le Roux and Myburgh was us in prison, we consulted together.
	I gave them my version and asked the Advocates to submit my application as close as possible to what I have given them.
Did you leave anything out of your application?
Sir, if I can say the biggest detail is not included but the matter that it is about, does appear.
Did you know that you were applying for amnesty for offences which you hadn't been convicted of?
Yes, Mr Chairperson, the day when I was sentenced in the High Court, the Judge I cannot remember his surname, the Judge said that I will be charged for everything.
Did he say you were found guilty for everything?
Are you guilty of the Bree Street bomb?
You had nothing to do with that?  You had nothing to do with planning it or committing that act at all?
No, I was not involved in the Bree Street bombing at all.
You went to Ventersdorp in April in order to protect the borders of your Volkstaat?
No, he said Mr Landman that the only reason going to Ventersdorp was the intention of stopping the elections.
It is different from the previous evidence.
Thank you.  Mr De Wet, maybe you can tell us again, why did you go to Ventersdorp?

Mr Chairperson, in Ventersdorp I worked there after I got a package at the mine.
	There I started a guard unit in order to protect Mr Terreblanche and his family as well as the Staff Generals.  Afterwards I left Ventersdorp because of, in order to build myself financially.  I was called up to go to Ventersdorp and it was there that I could not attend the Trim Park meeting.  I gave evidence today, it was the 21st or the 22nd according to Brigadier Leon van der Merwe, where I received the instructions that were given at Trim Park, from him.
What instructions did you receive at the Trim Park, at Brigadier van der Merwe?

Brigadier Van der Merwe, Johan Smit was there and it was told to me that it is war, that I must find a secure place where I could put my wife and children and later on, I will receive further instructions.
When you left your home and went to Ventersdorp, why did you go to Ventersdorp?
To go and hear what the instructions were that was given to the people at Trim Park.
Mr De Wet, at the time you went to Ventersdorp, that day, you didn't know what the reason was for being called to Ventersdorp?
No Mr Chairperson, I did not know.
And you ended up going to the game farm where you actually did, you became a guard to guard the farm, is that right?
Mr Chairperson, the day when I went to Ventersdorp and met Brigadier Van der Merwe to hear what his instructions were, I went back to my home and from there I left with the women to the game farm.
And there you carried out guard duties?
And were you also not to protect the borders of the Volkstaat?
No, the borders of the Volkstaat, there were other commando's in the area who did that.  My instruction there was that further instructions would be given to us.
Mr De Wet, if I can just take you to something else.  The farm where you saw the gas cylinder bomb being built, was that Koesterfontein?
Yes, that is correct.  That was the farm of Abraham Myburgh's father.
So that bomb was built away from the main group of AWB supporters who were at the game farm at the time, is that correct?
Yes, it was away from the group that stayed at the game farm.
And only a very few people knew about that, the group of people who were on Koesterfontein?
At that stage yes, I understood it that way.
And we know that the Bree Street bomb was built there, at Koesterfontein, do you agree with that?
The bomb for Germiston where you were involved, that was also built there?
Yes, it was also built at Koesterfontein.
The Jan Smuts bomb, where was that built?
Out of the court case I understood that it was at the shooting range in Rustenburg.
Would you agree with me Mr De Wet, that those people who moved to Ventersdorp and then later moved to the game farm, they were what one can describe at the "bitter einders"?
No, Mr Chairperson, there were other AWB members of the AWB Wenkommando from the Western Transvaal, who also gathered there.
Where were they, on whose farm were they?

Sir, just outside Brits on Mr Manie Maritz' farm there were also people, between Mooinooi and Brits, there was also a farm.  I do not know who the owner was, there were also people.  Near Koster, it is a holiday resort, there were also people there.
	On a farm near Ottosdal, I think it is Mr Koos Hough who was the owner of the farm, people were gathered there as well.  Also close to Klerksdorp people gathered.
Mr De Wet, when did you for the first time think or realise that maybe some of these people at Koesterfontein were responsible for the Bree Street bomb?
That evening, the Sunday evening when I arrived at Koesterfontein and I saw the gas bottle and explosives.
How well did you know Cliffie Barnard?
For the period when I was at Ventersdorp, worked there at the office, I knew him very well.
Have you had braais and brandy and Coke together?
What did you call him when you saw him at the AWB Headquarters?
He never said to you I don't want to be called by my rank?
No Mr Chairperson, he never said that.
Did other people also call him Colonel?
Yes Mr Chairperson, Mr Terreblanche also called him that and Mr Prinsloo, and other people who also worked at Head Office.
From time to time did ordinary members of the AWB come to the Headquarters and speak to Mr Barnard?
Mr Chairperson, the people from the area, the Western Transvaal district also came to the office and also addressed him as Colonel.
Isn't it strange that Mr Le Roux and Mr Fourie didn't know and never referred to Mr Barnard as Colonel?
Mr Chairperson, I cannot remember in that period when I worked at Ventersdorp that Mr Fourie or Mr Le Roux came to Ventersdorp at any stage.
Mr Fourie was an important man, he was one of the bodyguards of the leader, wasn't he?
Yes Sir, that is true, but they worked in another district and when Mr Terreblanche let's say go to Johannesburg or Witwatersrand, then Barnard wasn't always with him.
But he was at times with the leader in places like Johannesburg?
Yes, the times when he did drive with Mr Terreblanche, he did not wear his uniform.  I can concede to that.
So he normally wore a uniform at the office, at Headquarters?

No Mr Chairperson, in the office he did not wear his uniform.  He did though, or let me put it this way, he was a Colonel and I can confirm that in parades that we attended and when he was on a horse, he had the uniform of a Colonel.
Mr De Wet, I want to put it to you that you fabricate and you are making this up.
Mr Chairperson, that is what the Advocate says, my opinion is that it is the truth and that is how I knew Mr Barnard.
Just as you made up the evidence about seeing this gas bottle bomb at Koesterfontein.
No Mr Chairperson, I do not agree with that.
Did Mr Barnard ever give you any orders?
Did anyone give you orders to plant bombs?
Nico Prinsloo and Leon van der Merwe.
I do not know where he works at all Mr Chairperson.
Is he still a member of the AWB?
Are you a member of the AWB?
At this stage, no, not at all.
I am in prison and I do not mean anything for the AWB.
Do you believe they have abandoned you?
No, I would not say that they have abandoned me, there are some AWB members who still visit me in prison.
Has the leader ever come to visit you?
Has he ever admitted that the AWB was responsible for planting those bombs?
Yes, Mr Chairperson, in prison he at various times admitted that his Generals deserted him.
Sir, that is not an answer to the question.  My question is did Mr Terreblanche say to you directly that he and the AWB is responsible for the bombs that were planted?
Why did you never ask Mr Barnard whether he is the one who planted the bomb at Bree Street?
Mr Chairperson, I assumed that it was him and the group at Koesterfontein who made the bomb, I never asked him personally.
My question to you is why did you not ask him?  You know him well from Headquarters?
I did not ask him Chairperson.  I do not have a reason why I did not ask him.
Because you never really knew who had planted that bomb, did you?
I knew who planted the bomb in Bree Street after I was at Koesterfontein.
You knew or you had a suspicion?
I had a very good suspicion from what I saw at Koesterfontein, and I accepted it was them.
But did you know whether Mr Barnard was acting on orders of the AWB or whether this was his own adventure?

Mr Chairperson, I accepted that it was instructions from the AWB Head Office and that he wouldn't have done things on his own because General Nico Prinsloo and the people who were at the game farm, they knew about this.
	Therefore I accepted that it carried the approval of the AWB, Chairperson.
When on the game farm did somebody say that the AWB gave the order for the Bree Street bombing?

At the game farm those words were never spoken Chairperson, the fact that the AWB gave the instruction.
	I accepted it because Nico Prinsloo and Leon van der Merwe was there.
But they weren't at Koesterfontein, were they?
They weren't there as far as I know Chairperson.
When you went back to the game farm, did you tell anybody that you had seen Barnard and others making a bomb?
I spoke to Nico Prinsloo about it Chairperson.
Not that I can remember Chairperson.
Why would you want to tell General Prinsloo about this bomb?
Because I made my vehicle available to Prinsloo, I asked him about the vehicles that he promised Barnard.
I made mine available.  To me he was the General present there.
What was your motivation for telling him, just tell us?
Why did you tell General Prinsloo about the bomb at Koesterfontein, what was your reason?
Because I accepted that it was the AWB who was responsible for it.
Because we were busy with a freedom struggle.
Don't you think General Prinsloo would have known about it?
Most probably yes, he would have known about it.
Why didn't you tell the other people on the farm?
It was not an instruction that what you see and hear you should convey to other people, Chairperson.
Did Mr Barnard tell you that?
Mr De Wet, after the bomb exploded, wasn't there talk at the base camp and said we succeeded, we made the bomb explode and the battle has started?
There was no question of talk about the Bree Street bomb, only talk about the  pipe bombs and the Germiston, only after that there were talk about the bombs at the base.  Before that, not at all.
Did you whisper this or did you talk about it in the open?
After the Germiston bomb and the pipe bomb missions, we openly talked about it.
Mr De Wet, you say you saw on television that there had been a bomb in Bree Street, is that correct?
Inside the place where we lived Chairperson.
Is that at the game farm?
At the game farm, that is correct.
What did the people say when they saw this on television?
The feeling was that the war had started.
Was there any discussion about who might have been responsible?
We asked each other I wonder who did it.
No, I did not know at that stage.
Only the evening I went to Koesterfontein, then I assumed that it was them who were involved in this.
What time did you see the news, was it on television?
Yes, it was on television.  Seven o'clock or eight o'clock on television.
Did you then go to Koesterfontein after that?
The evening if I remember correctly, between eight o'clock and ten o'clock, that is when I went to Koesterfontein.
You see it on television, you see people making a bomb at Koesterfontein, why didn't you ask Mr Barnard, the person you know well, do you know anything about that bomb in Bree Street?
I did not ask questions at all and I cannot give a reason why I didn't ask questions either.
Were you scared of Mr Barnard?
Were you told at some stage that you must not ask questions?
Chairperson, when you are in a war situation, there are times when you do not ask questions, you just do as you are told.
But were you told not to ask questions?
In the training that I have had, I was taught that Chairperson.
On the television, or rather let me ask you this, how many times did you see a report about the Bree Street bomb on Sunday night?
Mr Chairperson, if I can remember correctly it was on the news twice, about seven/eight o'clock news and also later that evening, it was on CNN.
Did you hear that night that the BKA accepted responsibility for the bomb?
Did you know who the BKA were?

It was an organisation of which Constand Viljoen was the leader and other right wing parties such as Mr  Terreblanche, Ferdi Hartzenberg, Agricultural Unions as well as the Mining Unions, they all belonged to it.
	What the objective of the organisation was, I do not know.
Wasn't it meant to protect the farms, the farming areas?
Was it not meant to protect the farms in the area?
I do not know if that was the purpose.
Did you ever attend any meetings of the BKA?
Did the BKA have its own constitution?
Did you ask anybody whether they knew what the BKA was doing, seeing that they have accepted responsibility for this bomb?
No Mr Chairperson, I didn't ask anyone.
You have already mentioned another organisation called Boere Ordevolk, is that right?
Is it led by Mr Piet Rudolph?
Does it have its own constitution?
Certain points of his constitution is the same as the AWB, because we all wanted to get our own Volkstaat.
But it is a separate organisation from the AWB, isn't it?
The BKA was also separate from the AWB, wasn't it?
It had to be but it was still part of the AWB for me, because Terreblanche was involved with it.
All right.  Was the Freedom Front part of the Volksfront?
Was the Freedom Front part of the Volksfront?
No Mr Chairperson, it was a group that splintered away from the Volksfront.
So are you saying that when the BKA commits an act, it is actually the AWB who is committing that act?
No Chairperson, I do not say that.
Is it not possible Mr De Wet, that Mr Barnard could have been a member of the BKA?
Likewise Mr Le Roux, Ettiene le Roux?
And this might have been a small cell of people at Koesterfontein making bombs on behalf of BKA?
If you make the statement that way, I must accept that all the Officers who were at the game farm, must also have been part of the BKA.
This may have nothing to do with the AWB at all, this bombing campaign?
No, I wouldn't say that because all of us who were there, we gathered together there for the AWB, we did not belong to any other organisations, I didn't belong to other organisations.
You can only talk for yourself?
Assuming it was the BKA who planted that bomb in Bree Street, do you associate yourself with what the BKA did?
I understand that your amnesty application is based on a belief that that bomb was planted in support of the AWB's political struggle, is that correct?
Do you know what struggle the BKA was involved in?

Mr De Wet, at the time that you went to Ventersdorp to find out what the instructions were, did you at that stage have any idea as to whether or not you would get a Volkstaat, did you believe that there was still a chance that that might happen?
Chairperson, if you looked at the politics at that stage, the chances for us to obtain a Volkstaat, was impossible.
Mr De Wet, so did you understand at that stage that the only way to get a Volkstaat, was by way of violence?
No Chairperson, to wage a war.
What form would this war take?
By planting bombs, by taking up weapon and to shoot for what you want.
In connection with the Germiston bomb, what was the motive behind planting that particular bomb in that area where it was planted?
To stop the election and to stop chaos.
What would you achieve by stopping the election?
Then there would have been further negotiations with the National Party for a Volkstaat.
But you knew by that stage that you weren't going to get one, were you not convinced that no matter what you did ...
You asked me what we wanted to achieve by it and I told you what we wanted to achieve.
Mr De Wet, let me ask you this.  By the time you planted that first bomb, did you believe that you could stop the election?
Did you want people to rise up and oppose the government?
How was that going to come about?
Because of the chaos in the country and the bomb explosions and the people who do not go to the voting polls Chairperson.
When people were arrested, the people at the shooting range, or wherever, did you then think that the election could still be stopped?
No Chairperson, the arrests which took place made or ensured that the elections would be successful.
But did you realise that the elections could not be stopped when the arrests were made?
Chairperson, if they weren't all arrested at the shooting range, the group who was involved, there would still have been acts committed.
But the question is, you heard the people were arrested at the shooting range, did you then realise that the election cannot be stopped?
No Chairperson, I did not realise it then because I still believed that the other people who were still in the area in the Western Transvaal, that their actions or plans would also help.
When did you realise that the elections could not be stopped?
After the election took place and nothing else happened Chairperson.

Mr De Wet, getting back to what we were dealing with, if the elections didn't take place, who would revolt, who would take part in this revolution, would it be black people who would be revolting so that they can ...
No Chairperson, it would have been the people who reconciled themselves with the Volkstaat idea.
How were they going to revolt, can you describe what you anticipated would happen?
Chairperson, because bombs were already exploding before the elections and at meetings and marches which were held in towns, I believed by means of that, people would have started revolting.
So people would be leaving their houses in Primrose and in Homestead in Germiston after this bomb, and because they can't vote, and what would they be doing in the streets?
That is how I saw it Chairperson.
What will they be doing, what will they do?  Will they march up and down the streets?

Submissions would have been made to the government of the day and I believe if a bomb exploded, Terreblanche would have said to the government, if you do not listen to us, there will be another bomb, and there will be a bigger one and that is how I saw it at that stage.
Is this something which you understood from Mr Terreblanche's statements that this is what he intended doing?
Yes, with his speeches he made on stage, this is how I understood it.
For how many years were you Mr Terreblanche's bodyguard?

For the six months that I was in Ventersdorp I was personal bodyguard, and I accompanied him everywhere.
	In the Ystergarde you are both a bodyguard and instructor and when I was in his area, I would have been his bodyguard.  That is in the six months that I was in Ventersdorp.
When did you first attend a meeting addressed by Mr Terreblanche, was it years ago?
From the very first meeting I can remember was in the early 1980's, Chairperson.
Was he then talking about war?
That was at the time of P.W. Botha?
It was still in P.W. Botha's time, yes.
And then when Frederick took over, he then also talked about war against Mr De Klerk?
Mr Terreblanche just talks about war all the time, doesn't he?
It is a lot of hot air, isn't it, this war that he keeps talking about?
In his speeches people got whipped up.

Mr De Wet, you are obviously an intelligent person, didn't you understand that this is a man who talks about war ten years ago and ten years on, he is still talking about this war that never takes place?  Isn't that so?
You didn't believe him when he spoke about war, did you?
I believed that there would be a revolution, I believed that there would be a war Chairperson.
The best that he ever did, the best attempt that he ever had at war was going to Bophuthatswana on the back of bakkies and shooting at people there, isn't that so?
I cannot give comment on that Chairperson.
But you know about that incident?
Yes, I carry knowledge of that.
You know that he was eventually chased out there?
I do not know the circumstances that well, I do not want to testify to that Chairperson.
I want to understand how you felt.  This Bophuthatswana business happened in about February 1994, is that correct?
The so-called invasion into Bophuthatswana happened in about February 1994?
Weren't you working full-time for Mr Terreblanche at that stage?
What did you think of that invasion, did you think it was a success?
Sir, what I saw in TV, I can't say it was a success.
Did you after that, could you have faith in Mr Terreblanche and his organisation?
Yes Mr Chairperson, because what happened in Bophuthatswana was not the AWB's goal or purpose, they had their own Volkstaat and Mr Mangope wanted to help them.
Surely Mr De Wet, as an intelligent person, you could see that Mr Terreblanche was full of hot air and nothing more?  He never came to visit you at the game farm, did he?

That is true, I also did not expect him to come and visit us because he had other tasks to do and other duties to do.
	The Generals were there.
Do you know  of any other duties he performed in furtherance of this war, the revolution?
Yes, Mr Chairperson.  At meetings he addressed the people.
This is the same speeches he was giving when P.W. Botha was in power, isn't that so?
Isn't it so Mr De Wet, that ...

Mr Landman, without wanting to stop you, last week we called Mr Fourie out of order in an attempt as I understood, to cut down lengthy cross-examination unnecessary.  I am not saying your cross-examination is unnecessary, but where are we getting to with this?
Mr Chairman, if I can just move on to the next point.
I am making the point that each representative was going to deal with an incident and if he wasn't representing anybody who was interested in a particular incident, he would just go by.
I don't know, maybe I misunderstood the whole plan.

Mr Chairman, it became quite difficult to do it on that basis, but I am not going to be much longer with this witness.
	The thing is he said he associated himself with the Bree Street bomb, I am not quite sure whether that entitles him to amnesty or not, but that is an issue for the Committee at a later stage.
	I have just one last aspect.  Mr De Wet, do you know of an organisation or a philosophy called the Israeli Vision?

Mr Chairperson, with respect, you just made mention about cross-examination, but what has the Israeli Vision got to do with all the application?  Because in all the applications they say that they did it out of some religious stand point, if it was the Israeli Vision or any other church.
I am not saying that the question cannot be asked, it could have been a relevant question, I do not know.
Then the relevance must be indicated.
Mr Chairman, I take the point.  He said no, and I am not going to take it any further.  I have no further questions.

Thank you Mr Chairperson.  I will get a word in.
	Mr De Wet, just a few aspects.  How far did you get in school?
How far did you get in school?
I've got matric and I qualified myself in N6.
I am sorry, I did not hear.
Mr Chairperson, I qualified matric and after school I qualified with an N6 certificate.
Thank you.  You say that you were at the mine just before you took a package.  What type of work did you do at the mines?
Did you know anything about explosives?
Did you deal with any explosives?
No, at the mine where I worked I only saw some of the explosives around there.
Did you know about the dangers of explosives?
Koper Myburgh, what rank did he have within the Ystergarde?
In the Ystergarde, if I can remember correctly, he was a Lieutenant.
So you had a higher rank than him?
Was it Koper Myburgh who arrived at the game farm and specifically asked for you?

If you will just give me a moment Mr Chairperson.  You see paragraph 17, page 77 you say specifically on the 23rd of April, Koper Myburgh arrived at the game farm and he asked me to go to his father's farm in Koesterfontein?
That was after I was called into the meeting where they asked me if I wanted to join him in going to Koesterfontein.  Maybe I did not put it correctly.
So it was not Koper Myburgh who requested you specifically?
This war to which you at various times refer to, when would this have started?

Sir, when we gathered at the game farm, after we left the women, we accepted that the war started.
	When I arrived at Leon van der Merwe, he said it was war now, it was the 21st and the 22nd of April.
So before that there was no war?
No, there was a run up to the revolution, yes.
The war started on the 21st/22nd and not before that?
You said that you are willing to give you life?
For that which you believed in?
That is now the third time that you use those words, but you are not willing to give your vehicle?
No Sir, you made it conditionally available.
If I am not the driver, I will not give my vehicle, because I do not know what they will use my vehicle for.
But you will give your life?
This coalition that you refer to in paragraph 7 of your application, this Afrikaans Volksfront, if I may use the word, is that the vehicle of Constand Viljoen?
This Afrikaner Volksfront in paragraph 7, was this the party or Constand Viljoen, was he part of that?
And I accept that you believed that with General Constand Viljoen's people you would have been able to succeed?
If I understand Constand Viljoen correctly, he said that he will take part in the elections at about the 12th of March 1994?
He made the decision at that time, he took part in the election on the 27th of April?
Yes, I accept that but on the 12th of March he said I will not go into a war, but I will take part in the election, is that correct if I put it that way?
That was already the 12th of March when Viljoen decided not to take part in the war?
I do not know if he decided that completely, I cannot answer for him.
But Sir, it was very clear, there were boards up various parties that would take part and amongst them, Viljoen's party of the Freedom Front was also up.
Chairperson, when we gathered in Pretoria, all the right wing people said that we will not vote and I believed that Mr Constand Viljoen would also not vote because he was part of the meeting.
Did you know that he was going to take part in the elections?
He talked about him taking part in the elections, but what was said there at the meeting, this is my personal opinion, at that stage that he had a hidden agenda with that.
When did you find out that he was going to take part in the elections?
Was it before the march up or after?
I would say it was before the march to Ventersdorp, when the people were called up to go there.
You accept that approximately the 12th of March Viljoen would have decided to take part in the election?  When was the meeting in the Skilpad Hall?
So the talk about war was before the 12th of March?
Mr Chairperson, as I said already the run up to the election, things took place before that and talk about war, occurred before that.
But the person who would give you the most support, withdrew?
It was not the impression that I got, that he would completely withdraw.
In other words in the Western Transvaal, Constand Viljoen did not tie any placard against a pole for the election?
For me it was a set, a plan, it was a hidden agenda.
If I understand Mr Fourie correctly on Friday, you went to the game farm in order to protect the borders of the Volkstaat, is that correct?
Yes Mr Chairperson, that is how he gave evidence.
Do you agree with what he testified?
No, I do not agree with him.  There are certain things I do not agree with.
So why did you go to the game farm?
Because they told me that it is a war and you do not only protect the Western Transvaal's borders, you protect the whole country.
Mr De Wet, surely on the 27th of April 1994 it was then not a set or a plan, you had to realise that they were going to take part in the elections?
When did you realise that he is telling the truth, that he is going to take part in the elections?
Sir, I cannot say when I realised this, but it was after I was arrested that I realised that Mr Constand Viljoen did take part in the elections.
It was two, three months after the 27th.
But on the 27th you had to have realised that he is taking part in the elections?

Mr Chairperson, on the 27th, when they arrested the people at the shooting range, I started fleeing, I was on the run because our people were arrested.  For a few days I did not watch the news, I cannot say what happened there.
Just to follow up on the question of the Chairperson.  During the period of the 12th of March up to the elections, did you have a television in your house, did you buy a newspaper?
No Mr Chairperson, I did not have a television and I was also not a person who read newspapers.
Were you also part of the HNP?
You say that the war was declared around the 21st or the 22nd of April 1994?
Yes, they said that we are going to make war.
Who chose the target in Germiston?
Did you discuss it at any time with your fellow men?
No, I was only at Koesterfontein the evening, and the next afternoon ...
Did you ever discuss things or talked to each other at Koesterfontein?
I was not at Koesterfontein, I only went to go and drop off the pipe bombs.
And then you went back the next morning?
Yes, to go and get the trailer.
And didn't you talk with your fellow soldiers?
No, the morning we got the instructions that this is going to Germiston and how we must transport this trailer.
Sir, did you see the bomb in the trailer?
At what stage did you see the gas burner?
The evening when I was at Koesterfontein, it was on a table and explosives were stuck around it.
The next morning, where was that explosive and gas bottle?
I do not know, I was not in the building again.  I got Mr Le Roux's vehicle with a trailer along the road.
Are you saying now that you did not know what was in the trailer?
They said there to me that the bomb was in the trailer.
And didn't you receive any further instructions to put sand in the trailer?
Before I got there, they were busy to load sand into the trailer.
Because I saw it Mr Chairman,  when I got there.
In other words, you did see the trailer?
There was sand on top of the gas bottle, I did not see it.
Was it only sand that you saw inside the trailer?
I only saw the sand, yes.
What type of bomb would you take to Germiston?
I accepted that it was the gas bottle bomb.
So you knew how big that bomb would be?
Yes, it was full of soil.
Sir, what I cannot understand is why did four of you have to drive through?
I was the driver of my vehicle.
And the person who drove with me, had to detonate the bomb.  The vehicle in front could have one or two, it would be the guide vehicle.
Why did that vehicle have to have two people?
It could have been one, I do not know why there were two.
Did you see what damage that Germiston bomb did?
Only that which I saw on television, and also the photographs that were at the court case.
So you saw what damage that bomb did?
When you unhooked the trailer, who were with you?
Did you not at that stage tell Vlok that we are now at a taxi rank, we must not detonate the bomb here?
No, I did not say that.
Were you happy with the choice of the target?
We were told that they will tell us where we must detonate the bomb, and I kept with the order that was given.
The only difference was that the vehicle said that the bomb must be detonated here, all that I did was drove around the block and parked in the parking lot, and that was the order.
And there were a lot of people and taxi's?
Do you know how many people were killed in the Germiston bombing?
And in the court case, did you find out how big that bomb was?
They talked about 100 kilograms, if I can remember correctly, 100 kilograms of explosives.
Yes, they said the bomb was 100 kilograms.  I do not know what they meant by 100 kilograms.
Did you realise how big that bomb was that bodies were thrown up to the ten storey building?
Yes Mr Chairperson, I heard that in the court case.
Sir, your application in the AWB, you said that you have to be an Afrikaner and a Christian?
Was that the action of an Afrikaner and a Christian?
Yes, Mr Chairperson, I was in a war situation and everything that I had to achieve, I see that as a Christian way.
In other words that bomb is within that parameter?
You said earlier on to Mr Landman, that you are currently not a member of the AWB because you are of no use to them?
And if you do get amnesty, will you again join the AWB?
Sir, at this stage I do not want to involve myself with any politics, I just want to continue with my life.

Sir, listening to you I must at the outset tell you that, I am asking myself if you are telling us the whole truth as you know it.
	Tell me Sir, ordinarily who do you expect to get the instructions from if you go out on any operation?
Mr Chairperson, that it would carry the approval of the leader of the AWB and Staff Generals and the Officers above me, it should carry their approval.

And Sir, is it correct that as a trained soldier you expected things to be done in an orderly fashion, you knew that if actions are to be carried out, there will be specific cells or groups for that purpose and things would be done in an orderly fashion, didn't you?
Now, talking about the Germiston bomb, did you belong to any cell or any group that was responsible for any operations?
I belonged to the AWB at that stage Chairperson.

Sir, the impression I have is that even within the AWB and further within the Ystergarde, somebody seems to have been appointed at some stage, to be in charge of the operations unit, is that impression correct?
That is correct Chairperson, there were people who were appointed to do certain tasks.
Now my question to you is, did you belong to any of these special operation units?
No Mr Chairperson, I was only a member of the group who gathered together at the game farm and part of the bomb missions.

And just to understand you further, are you saying that as far as the Germiston bomb is concerned, it was by mere chance, you collided into it, you didn't know about its planning, hardly did you know that it was going to be there in the first place, you just happened to be called there to make your motor vehicle available and there you were, finding yourself in Germiston on such a big mission?

That is correct Chairperson, of the planning of that bomb, I knew nothing.  Koekemoer who was involved in court, he testified that I helped building the bomb, but that is a lie, I did not help in building the bomb at all.
On the way to Germiston, did you know what you were transporting?
Yes, I was told it was going to be a bomb which should be planted in Germiston.
Sir, you say that when you were in Germiston, you realised that this was a black taxi rank?
Chairperson, all that I saw when I arrived in Germiston was that it was a taxi stand and that there were buildings around it.
Is it then your evidence that you didn't know that this was a black taxi rank?
No Chairperson, there were black people, I can tell you that.  I do not know if there were other people, there were whites present as well.
Okay, talking about the war and be mindful of the fact that you are a trained soldier.  Did you have any targets in your war?
No Chairperson, we did not have specific targets.  I wasn't told that we had specific targets.  The fact was that the elections had to be stopped at all costs.

Talking about the bombs that came before you could move over to Ventersdorp and therefore let's say, talk about the bomb on the 23rd/24th, before then, the other bombs that had gone off, were you aware of what the policy of the AWB was regarding the planing of these bombs, with particular reference to who would be the target?
Chairperson, what I did know was that the targets which were pointed out at that stage, was NP offices as well as ANC offices.

It seems to me Sir, correct me if I am wrong, going by the report that has been distributed here where Mr Terreblanche was talking about more bombs are coming, if one looks at that report, it seems to me that even if one was to talk about the bombs in Lichtenburg and Leeudoringstad, these were directed at specific targets like an electrical pylon apparently and Leeudoring one, directed at the railway line.  Isn't it that you had a specific pattern of going about identifying your targets as the AWB?
Chairperson, what the planning was, I do not know.  I do not know if they had deliberate targets, but what I did know was that NP and ANC offices were bombed at that stage.

Let me put it differently, up to the time that you moved over to Ventersdorp, the impression I have here, and please tell me if this is not also  your impression, is that you were targeting things like offices, power stations, railway lines, government things or political things if one may put it in those terms, is that impression correct?
And Sir, all the meetings that you attended, where Mr Terreblanche amongst others talked, did any of them say to you that there is now a change in the attitude of the choice of targets?
No Mr Chairperson, it was never put to me in that way.
In fact nobody ever said to you that now it is time that innocent civilians must be killed otherwise you would have long told us about it?  Did anybody say that to you?
No Chairperson, nobody told me to go and kill innocent people.
And Sir, as a trained soldier, I think it is pretty obvious to you that when you are involved in a war situation, you don't go about killing innocent civilians, am I correct?

Mr Chairperson, what I learnt from waging a war is that innocent people too die in a war situation - people who are not interested in politics.  It doesn't matter what country's war this is.
	Innocent people do get killed.  But nobody actually told me to go and kill innocent people, those were just the circumstances.
Yes.  If innocent civilians get caught in the cross-fire, it seems to me that that is unfortunate, but they are not really the target, isn't that?
No Mr Chairperson, they are not the target but they were there by coincidence, caught up in the cross-fire.
Let's talk now about the Germiston bomb.  Who was the target?
Mr Chairperson, I do not know of any target, I was only told to go and plant the bomb there.
By the way, why do you say you moved to Ventersdorp, I understand it was a call up, but what was your understanding, why did you have to move to Ventersdorp?
Mr Chairperson, the first time I went there was when I went to work there, I took a package from my job, otherwise I would have lost it because of Affirmative Action.
No, I mean around the 20th or 21st of April?
Brigadier Leon van der Merwe called me up with regards to what was discussed at the Trim Park on the previous occasion.
You say that you did not know what was the purpose of being called up to Ventersdorp?
At that stage, I did not know the purpose.  I only learnt that on the 21st/22nd, then I found out why people were specifically called up to Ventersdorp.

Sir, now that we know that the Ystergarde seems to have been the elite group within the AWB, would it be fair to say that a member of the Ystergarde would then reasonably be expected to know what the AWB stands for and what is being planned, at least the Officers have to know what is being planned Sir?  Would it be fair?
Would it then be fair to say that the Officers who belonged to the elite, being the Ystergarde, would reasonably not be expected to know what is being planned?
Mr Chairperson, the Ystergarde was there for personal protection, they were not there to know what was being discussed between Mr Terreblanche and his Generals.

In fact, if action was to be taken would it, I am talking about now not defensive action but to go on the attack, if action was to be taken, would it be the Ystergarde to do it or would it be the Wenkommando, or who would do it?
I believe the Ystergarde would have received the instructions for attacking.
Did the Ystergarde ever get such instructions?
Not that I know of Chairperson.
And Sir, talking about you driving your motor vehicle to Germiston, why did you make it a condition that if your car is to be made available, the condition would be that you must be the driver?

Chairperson, a vehicle when you work, a vehicle is the only way of transport from and to work and it is a very important thing.  You cannot, in the Western Transvaal you cannot walk.  The towns are far apart.
Mr (indistinct) is has been said that cars are the toys of men, and they protect it.
But Sir, isn't it that you were prepared to lose all your possessions if need be, including your life for the struggle?
That is correct Chairperson, I was prepared to give my life, but my vehicle, I had my wife and children, and they needed a vehicle if they wanted to move from point A to point B.
Okay, going back to the Germiston bomb.  Who gave you the instructions that you must go and place this bomb at Germiston?
That was the morning  when I was at Koesterfontein, and Mr Barnard told us that the bomb was going to Germiston.
Did the members of the Ystergarde wear uniform?
Chairperson, when we got together for the war, we didn't wear our uniforms at all.
Let's talk about before the war, or before you move ...
Before the war we did wear uniforms, yes.
Did you ever see Mr Barnard wearing a uniform to show that he belongs to you, the Ystergarde?
Mr Chairperson, Mr Barnard's hair was long and because of that, he wasn't allowed to wear the Ystergarde uniform, but I did see him in the camouflage uniform of the Wenkommando.
You saw him in uniform of the Wenkommando?

And being a member of the Ystergarde and having some basic understanding of the chain of command within the Ystergarde, isn't it that you expected that if instructions were to come to you about operations, they have to come within the line of command within your structure, the Ystergarde, is that correct?

I am saying if instructions were to be given to you regarding operations that you were to go out on, you would expect that whoever gives you instructions, has to be somebody within the Ystergarde, not the Wenkommando, is that not so?
So far as the Ystergarde is concerned, you cannot say what was Barnard in it, correct?

Chairperson, my view of Barnard - we concluded our course together in the Ystergarde, so he was a member of the Ystergarde, and if I remember he completed it successfully, so he must have been a Captain within the Ystergarde.
Did he ever wear any badge to show his rank?
Yes, in the Wenkommando he carried the rank of Colonel.
No, not in the Wenkommando, in the Ystergarde?
I already said in the Ystergarde Barnard did not wear the Ystergarde uniform because of his long hair.
Am I then correct to say that you did not know what his rank would be within the Ystergarde?
Yes, Chairperson, as far as I was concerned Barnard was a Captain within the Ystergarde.
You say that before this pre-election bombs, you were told to forget about the ranks?
Could the speaker please repeat the question.
Can you just repeat your question, please Sir?
Did you say that before these pre-election bombings, you were told to forget about the ranks?
When we went to Leon van der Merwe, his house, he said that we will not have ranks any more because we are going to the war situation, that is correct.
And you are saying that this did not mean that the ranks didn't exist, all that was being said was that you didn't have to mention them any more?
I said that when in public we act, or in a war situation where we are amongst people, we are not allowed to address him as Colonel or Major, whatever, you must address him by his name.

Because I want to suggest to you that to the extent that I may believe you when you say that Mr Barnard told you to take the bomb to Germiston,  I want to suggest that he was on a frolic of his own.  He together with the small grouping that you say you saw at Koesterfontein, where the majority of the people were not, that little group were on a frolic of their own, and you became part of it?

Mr Chairperson, I cannot say that because after I spoke to General Nico Prinsloo and also Brigadier Leon van der Merwe, and the instructions we got from the pipe bomb missions, if it did not have the approval of the AWB, I do not think it would have happened.
Did it have the approval of the AWB?
Did the whole operation have the approval of the AWB?
Yes, I accepted it because the Generals were with us at the base.
Sir, look, but if we talk about Koesterfontein, did you see any General there?  When you went to pick up the bombs and drop it at Germiston, were any of the Generals there?
Mr Chairperson, if Mr Barnard asked General Prinsloo that must be stolen, where are the vehicles that must be made available, then I believe that they did know what was going on at Koesterfontein.
This is but your own conclusion?
Yes, that is my own conclusion.
If you had known that the bomb in Germiston would kill so many people and injure so many, would you still have planted it?

Mr Chairperson, I was in a war situation and irrespective of how many people died, I cannot say if there were more or less people who died, I cannot say if I would have associated myself or not, I was part of the group and I associated myself with what occurred.

Look Sir, I can see that you are at pains to always stress about how you associated yourself with everything that took place, but for me there is a clear distinction between associating and something that you knew you would have done beforehand.
Out of my own I would not have done it.  If I as an individual or if I did not belong to an organisation, I would not have done it and if I was not in a war situation, I also would not have done it.

Because I am suggesting further that when you wage war, you don't make innocent civilians your target and to the extent that you and your group went about it in that fashion, I suggest that it could not have been a legitimate war, you are fighting the innocent civilians?
Mr Chairperson, for me it was war and the instructions I received, I executed them as far as I could.
I am not sure if I understand you well, do you agree with my submission that the way things turned out to be, this could not be justified under any circumstances?
No, I do not agree with what you say.
Are you saying that for you to get the Volkstaat, you regarded it as perfectly legitimate for you to go about killing and maiming innocent civilians?
No Mr Chairperson, it was not the idea to kill innocent people, we were in a war situation and some people die within the cross-fire.  I will not say that they were the target.
I've got a problem with this idea that you talk about innocent and people in cross-fire, or people in the cross-fire.  For someone to be in a cross-fire, there must be a target?

Mr Chairperson, that morning at Koesterfontein, they told me that the bomb would go to Germiston.  Where the bomb had to be planted, at that stage, I did not know.  I did not know the Germiston area, so I cannot say that it had a target or there was a target, or specific targets were appointed.
	For me, the election had to be stopped at all costs and I did not know where to place the bomb.
And you just executed orders or followed orders?
Because we were in a war situation Mr Chairman, I did not question it.
Yes, I could if I wanted, but at that stage I did not think about questioning it.

Sir you are saying that you did not know then what was the target.  Let me put it this way, if it was to be found that the real target was the black people or the black commuters at the taxi rank, would you still associate yourself with what took place?
Mr Chairperson, if it was an instruction, I would have done it, yes.

No, no, I understand the question of instructions.  I understand the question of instructions, it seems to me you are arguing or submitting that if you get an instruction, you simply have to comply with them, correct?
Mr Chairman, if I had to give the command and if I had to do it by myself, I would not have planted the bomb at a taxi rank.  If that is what your question was.
I've got no further questions, Mr Chairperson.
Mr De Wet, you are a new kind of guerrilla to me, you fought volk and father land, but not the motor vehicle, is that correct?
Mr Chairperson, for God and the father land, that is correct, but not the vehicle, my vehicle has got nothing to do with that.  For me it was my God, my father land and my nation.

I am not joking Mr De Wet, it seems to me your evidence comes down to this, that you wanted to drive your vehicle, because you wanted to preserve it for your family if something happened to you, and that if General anything had said to you, we want to use your vehicle for a bomb, you would have said no, because this is your precious car?

Mr Chairperson, when I arrived at Koesterfontein and told them that I am driving with a bomb to Germiston, I was prepared to give everything because if the car was in the back of my car and it was detonated there and the time span that available for me, I would not have time to unhook the trailer, etc.
You weren't prepared to give your vehicle away, what changed over night?
I made my vehicle available Mr Chairperson.
You see, we know until you got to Koesterfontein, you didn't know where you were going with that vehicle at all.

Mr Chairperson, when I arrived at Koesterfontein, I was asked to go and hear from the General where is the vehicle that is available.  I went there to General Prinsloo and asked him the person is asking for the vehicle, for a specific vehicle with a tow equipment and I said we do not have such a vehicle.
	At that stage I did not know what it was for.
That is precisely, you didn't know what your vehicle was needed for until you got to Koesterfontein?
Except the fact that you have been to fetch pipe bombs the day before?
I picked it up that evening, yes.

You see as I understand your evidence it is this and correct me if I am wrong, because as far as I am concerned, your answers to my learned friend, have killed your amnesty application.
